Award.AwardTitle: CCSS-CPS: Collaborative: If the Bridges Can Talk: Toward Autonomous Structure Health Monitoring for Civil Infrastructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the research is to develop fully autonomous Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) system
consisting of sensors organically integrated within the structure, free of wire leads and external power sources. Central to the proposed approach are the multi-functional piezoelectric transducer-based smart aggregates, which can transform ambient energy to electricity power, modulate useful information on stress waves for communication, and generate and receive stress waves for detection of structural defects.

Intellectually, the project will advance the knowledge regarding communication over concrete conduits
through: i) Measurement-driven characterization of SA transceivers and concrete channels under different
loading conditions, and ii) Design of modulation schemes for acoustic communications in concrete channels. The project aims to develop a holistic system solution through: i) the development of energy harvesting and storage modules, in conjunction with low-power circuits, and ii) Design and evaluation of energy-aware task
scheduling.

The proposed research is expected to generate far-reaching broader impacts in science, education, and
society. Our systems-based research integrates innovative research on hardware, algorithms, and
architectures to enable the next generation of cyber systems. It also integrates educational activities in real-life infrastructure building, communications systems, and networking. In the near term, the basic building blocks developed for communication and energy harvesting can help extend existing wireless-based,
battery powered systems, making these systems more fault tolerant and energy efficient. In the long term,
the project outcomes can provide impetus for wide-spread integration of fully autonomous SHM systems as
the technology matures, leading to improved public safety and reduced maintenance costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes in Intellectual merits: With the vision that future civil infrastructure is equipped with a fully autonomous Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) system consisting of sensors organically integrated in the structure free of wire leads and external power sources, in this project we proposed a plan for system-oriented activities in collaborative, multidisciplinary, and integrative research on Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) technologies to address societal concerns on our nation’s aging infrastructure systems. The key contribution is the unitary framework for sensing, actuation and communication, and power of the SHM system, which allows a concrete structure to perform self-diagnosis periodically powered by energy harvested from vibration or stress induced by vehicles and pedestrians. At the core of the proposed solution is the multifunctional piezoelectric transducer, which can transform ambient energy to electricity (power); modulate useful information on stress waves (communication); and generate and receive stress waves to detect structural defects (sensing). We assembled a strong research team from University of Houston (UH) and UC-Davis with expertise in communication, mechanical systems and sensor design, and networking to advance this ambitious and transformative agenda. The following summarizes our major findings:

- We characterized single-input single-output (SISO) and multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) concrete channels and determined the potential capacity limits of smart aggregate (SAs) for stress wave communication. This study demonstrated the feasibility of concrete channel for communication.

- We developed a high efficiency stress wave communication system and compared the performance of phase shift keying (PSK) with quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM).

- We innovatively developed a time reversal based pulse position modulation (TR-PPM) for stress wave communication within the concrete structure to combat multipath propagation features and dispersive nature of stress waves.

- We designed energy transfer circuit based on the LTC3588 chip from Linear Technology. We demonstrated that the developed energy harvesting module can accumulate enough energy over a long period to provide enough high and long duration current for the sensor under the network joining and operational state.

- We designed an interface between the energy harvesting module and the wireless sensor node to optimize the power charging efficiency of the energy harvesting circuit.

- We designed the energy-efficient state scheduling scheme for senor nodes.

- We developed a time reversal based novel synthesis method for remotely charging the wireless devices located in the difficult access area by utilizing guided stress waves traveling along the structures.

- We have demonstrated the stress wave based communication and damage detections for monitoring of concrete structures.

Outcomes in Broader impacts: The proposed research is expected to have far-reaching broader impacts in science, education and quality of life. The following summarizes major impacts of the project:

- Offered dissertation/thesis opportunities and training to graduate students. The project directly enabled two PhD dissertations and two MS theses. The project offered training or partial training to a total of 6 doctoral students and 3 MS students.

-Benefited undergraduate education. The experiments and demonstrations developed in this project was integrated into three undergraduate courses. Students learned about piezoceramic based energy harvesting and stress wave communication.
